results.title: Puzzle children
results.creator_credit: Bill Davis, Stephen Beck and WQED
results.brief_description: Discusses learning disabilities in children and identifies some of the myths that prevent an accurate understanding of these problems. Profiles four children with specific learning handicaps. Including comments by their parents, teachers, and special educators. Hosted by Julie Andrews and Bill Bixby.

results.title: Wilderness: The Himalayas
results.creator_credit: Ned Kelly, British Broadcasting Corporation and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description: Narrator Anthony Smith journeys from India to Tibet along an ancient foot highway which unites the two countries. Highlights the fauna, flora and people en route. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Tuareg
results.brief_description: A six year drought in the Sahel desert has forced the Tuareg to abandon their traditional nomadic ways. The film examines the changes in the structure and lifestyle of the Tuareg and looks at Community Aid Abroad projects which are helping them to establish a new way of life.

results.title: Last hunting ground
results.brief_description: A fishing trip by the “Southern Bluefin”, one of the Safcol fishing fleet hunting for the Southern Blue Fin tuna along the South Australian coast. Shows the crew in action spotting and catching fish for two days and then returning home with a load of Blue Fin tuna. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Magic well
results.brief_description: An adaptation of the Grimm Brothers fairy tale “Frau Holle”, in which two sisters journey to an enchanted land where kindness is rewarded by Mother Holle. Shows how the girls’ jouneys have very different results.

results.title: Science: new frontiers: is the weather changing?
results.brief_description: Discusses the importance of correlating patterns of human behaviour with ecological survival. This is based on scientific findings which suggest that radical changes in climatic conditions may be the result of human activities. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Blowgun
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Explains that in a single day a Makiritare craftsman tailors a blowgun with precision fittings that will last for years. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Bernstein on Beethoven: a tribute
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Burton, Amberson Productions and CBS
results.brief_description: Leonard Bernstein traces the life of Beethoven and plays sections from the “Piano Concerto No.1 in C Major” in a musical celebration of Beethoven’s Bicentennary at the Vienna Festival of Music. Suitable for Upper Secondary level students.

results.title: Art of the sixties
results.creator_credit: Merrill Brockway, Bailey Film Productions and WCBS-TV
results.brief_description: This film documents the major directions in modern American art during the first seven years of the 1960’s. The keynote is that the artist has expanded the realm of art from the two-dimensional picture frame, climaxed by the artists of the 40’s and early 50’s, merged colour with sculpture, and sought out modern media to produce the characteristic wide spectrum of interests, ideas and products in the art of our time. The works of about 15 artists are represented, including George Segal’s life-size plaster representational figures, Klaus Oldenburg’s monumental Pop works, Donald Judd’s hard-edge two and three-dimensional paintings and Robert Rauschenberg’s three-dimensional objects in motion. The narrator discusses the collaboration between the artist and the modern industrial craftsman in certain complex works. The interesting focus on environmental art which has brought art beyond the third dimension is exemplified by several artists working together on “happenings”; by the sound and motion production models for the future by Len Lye, and by Les Levine’s work with Mylar, light and air. Narrated by Leonard Harris. Suitable for upper secondary level.
